messageBody:
Looks interesting, although I have a word of warning for you: I worked
with the Blaze rules engine for three years. It tried to essentially
create an English-like Java/business rules hybrid. It never reached the
point where nontechnical people could easily use it to do anything
useful, and that was its overriding goal. I suspect your goal is
similar. It is a difficult goal to reach, so I suggest either throwing
yourself into making ESL very easy for nontechnical people to use, or
don't bother trying. If you create something somewhat in the middle,
you'll just anger both sides. (I have plenty of personal experience on
this one.)

Also, please don't name interfaces with "IF" at the end. A good OO
design doesn't distinguish among kinds of types: concrete classes,
abstract classes and interfaces should all look the same. An interface
is a role a class can play, so name it that way without extra
decoration. Let the Javadoc tell me it's an interface.

I have tried something similar, and have found it difficult to do it in
a domain-neutral way. It always ended up looking like a clunky
BASIC/Java hybrid. Let me suggest that you pick a business domain to
target and concentrate on that. You'll be more effective that way, even
if you reach fewer people.

Please don't think I'm discouraging you. I'm just trying to push you
down a brighter tunnel than the one you seem to be going down. :)
